course_title: Introduction to Second Language Learning and Teaching

learning_outcomes.description: Understand key theories, concepts and processes involved in additional language learning and teaching.
Effectively analyse a range of issues influencing second and foreign language learning and teaching, including learner, pedagogical, and contextual factors.
Reflect on and critically evaluate your own language-learning experiences in light of second language acquisition theories to enhance your ongoing academic development as a language learner.

Apply core pedagogical principles and knowledge of the history and development of second and foreign language teaching methodologies to plan, justify and evaluate evidence-based approaches to language teaching.
Demonstrate effective interaction and collaboration skills in diverse communicative and group-work settings to support shared learning outcomes.
Effectively use appropriate digital technologies to translate theoretical concepts into meaningful learning experiences (e.g. digital artefacts).

assessments.task_description:
You are required to complete a weekly pre-class online quiz before class session. To prepare for the quiz, please complete the assigned readings and listen to the online lecture each week. Quiz questions may include multiple-choice, True/False, matching, and fill-in-the-blank formats. Each quiz consists of 10 questions, and the quiz link will be available on Blackboard/ Assessment/ Assessment Task 1: Pre-class Quiz.

Each quiz will open at 12 pm on Tuesdays and will be due at 1pm the following Monday, giving you six days to prepare and complete the quiz at a convenient time. For example, Quiz 2 opens at 12 pm on Tuesday, 24 February 2026, and is due at 1pm on Monday, 2 March 2026. Please check the due date for each quiz below.

You have only ONE attempt to complete the quiz. You will have a maximum of 15 minutes to complete it. An automatic timer will begin when you start the quiz, so please complete the required reading BEFORE starting the quiz.

HURDLE REQUIREMENT

There are 10 quizzes scheduled across the semester in Weeks 2-4 and 6-12. You must complete at least 6 out of the 10 quizzes to meet the hurdle requirement. Failure to meet this requirement will result in failing the course.

assessments.task_description:
This is an in-class exam held during the Week 5 Tutorial

The exam will be done on paper.

Duration: 90 minutes (plus 10 minutes preparation time).

In this assessment, you will analyse second language learner data using the course content from Modules 1-4, focusing mainly on the Contrastive Analysis Hypothesis (CAH) and Error Analysis (EA). You will be provided with two short written texts produced by EFL learners from different first language backgrounds, reflecting on their experiences of studying abroad. The texts contain a range of linguistic errors (e.g. grammar and vocabulary) commonly found in second language learning.

You are required to identify and analyse selected errors in the learner texts and explain the potential reasons for these errors drawing on CAH and EA (e.g. transfer errors or developmental errors). You will also be asked to propose pedagogical activities that address selected learner errors, demonstrating how theoretical insights can inform instructional practice. In addition, you will reflect on similarities between the observed learner errors and your own experiences of learning a second language and evaluate the usefulness of CAH and EA for learning and/or teaching contexts.

This assessment evaluates your ability to apply SLA theory to authentic learner data and pedagogical situations.

Generative AI & MT Statement

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Form a group of three and design a SLA website to introduce SLA Theories using lay language and personal experience to non-SLA audiences including key aspects of the theories, personal stories, teaching implications and review of SLA research. The length of the website is approximately 1500 words (i.e. 500 words per student). Procedures, guidelines and format will be discussed at length in the tutorials.

assessments.task_description:
You are required to:

(1) watch a series of video demonstrations of EFL/ESL teaching methods and discuss these methods during the tutorials,

(2) participate in two language lessons in which basic phrases and vocabulary of a less commonly taught language are taught and practised. These language lessons will be taught within Week 11 and Week 12 tutorials, and

(3) complete a language quiz after attending the two language sessions to assess how much you have learned. Completing the test will be part of the assessment but the actual score of this language quiz that you receive will not be taken into account. 

Based on the above participation, you are then required to write a reflective essay on your language learning experience. You are required to:

- Reflect on the teaching methods used by the tutor in comparison with the three teaching methods discussed during the tutorials, as well as aspects you found more and less challenging in the course of the lessons.

- Relate your experience to the language learning theories and approaches discussed in the textbook.

- Consider a range of factors including the effectiveness of using only the target language, the role of written language in spoken language learning, possible differences between the different domains - pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar, and so on.

Procedures, guidelines and essay format will be presented in the tutorials.

Word length - 2000 words
